video.title: Avatar: Frontiers of Pandora | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text: Second Wind
[Intro Music]

Experience has taught me never to expect much
of big studio games that&#39;d come out in mid-December,

too late for any game awards
or to go on anyone&#39;s Christmas lists.

Let&#39;s just say that when a dog gets
vertically kicked out of a car in the middle of nowhere,

it doesn&#39;t speak terribly well for the
amount of faith the owner had in the dog&#39;s ability
to not whittle on the carpet.

Which is odd because last I checked,
James Cameron&#39;s Avatar the Last Smurfbender is a
fucking red-hot piece of pop culture IP.

The last Avatar movie did
gangbusters in theatres, apparently.

I mean, I didn&#39;t see it, and I&#39;ve never
met anyone who has or is enthusiastic about Avatar

or even gives it much thought at all
unless they&#39;re watching Dances with Wolves on a TV

with dodgy colour
correction, which makes me suspicious.

Maybe there&#39;s an unknown subsection of
humanity living among us, presumably dwelling underground

and subsisting on rats and stray dogs,
who emerge from the sewer drains at night to watch

Avatar movies and send phone
votes into America&#39;s Next Top Model.

Or maybe James Cameron is buying up
millions of empty theatre seats to pad his numbers

when he&#39;s not buggering off to the bottom
of the ocean to scrape bits of dead billionaire
off the Titanic.

But anyway, in Avatar Frontiers of
Pandora we play one of the central big skinny blue

twats who was kidnapped and raised by
humans to act as ambassadors, with our main human

point of contact being a sneering white
guy with his shirt very self-righteously tucked

into his big boy pants who shoots our
sister dead and seems really personally offended

about our lack of gratitude when we escape
his armed death squads and flee into the jungles
of Pandora.

Yeah, Avatar&#39;s nothing if not as subtle
as an attention-starved Alsatian in a prison
riot.

Ooh, humans are huge, greedy land-stealing
bastards in the Na&#39;Vi, a perfect and peace-loving
and noble and one with nature.
Now look here, James Camerahead.

It&#39;s very easy to be one with nature
when nature is as weirdly fucking obliging as it
seems to be on Pandora.

It&#39;s easy to be nice when you live in the
garden at the start of Wonka&#39;s Chocolate Factory

and there&#39;s food everywhere and
there&#39;s a fucking naturally occurring free internet

anyone can connect to with the ethernet
cable stuck up their bum and you can literally fling

yourself off a fucking cliff and count
on the pterodactile uber service to catch you
before you hit the ground.

I think the Na&#39;Vi need
to check their planet privilege.

I jumped on a seagull once and not a
whole lot came of it, although admittedly I was

motivated more by revenge
than a need for transportation.

Let&#39;s get to the meat and bones
of this particular obliterated seagull.

Avatar fraternity of pillocks is a
Ubisoft sandbox set on Pandora, and I think what might

explain the
publisher&#39;s apparent lack of enthusiasm

is that it&#39;s the most
painfully fucking by-the-numbers
Ubisoft sandbox I&#39;ve played in some time.
More specifically, it&#39;s Avatar Far Cry.
It&#39;s Avatar Cry.

Lots of firing arrows out of the
undergrowth at oblivious dudes with very short patrol
routes.

So there&#39;s stealthing and there&#39;s direct
combat, but the array of different gameplay threads

can&#39;t give each other enough room to
breathe and every core gameplay loop feels like it&#39;s
missing something.

Normal humans are as threatening to your
big blue arse as inexpensive toilet paper, so

the game is flooded with dudes in mecha
suits, and if your arrow is two pixels off from their

instakill weak spots everyone is
instantly alerted and knows your position, so stealthing
is kind of a bust.

And then all the enemy AI knows how to do
in combat is charge your position while holding

down the fire button,
so the combat&#39;s a bust as well.

If you&#39;re not in cover, your health
disappears so fast you wonder why you&#39;re even bothering

to craft better armour, because the
difference in life expectancy between Gear Score 11 and
Gear Score 12 has to be measured in nanoseconds.
And now we&#39;re getting to it.

The three pillars of the Jiminy
Cockthorpe model stand erect and throbbing.

You&#39;ve got your shitty stealth, your
shitty action, and you bet your big blue blistered
bollocks you&#39;ve got shitty crafting as well.

What makes it shitty is that I assumed
the whole selling point was being able to go out

into Pandora and whet yourself in
admiration over the transcendent beauty of the alien
scenery.
But it&#39;s hard to appreciate the warm sensation of

your piss-filled
loincloth when you then have to

turn on your fucking smurf-o-vision and
comb the air you&#39;re isolating what bits of it you&#39;re

supposed to be harvesting
to craft your essential upgrades.

I go to the crafting table to upgrade by
currently equipped sanitary towel or whatever and it&#39;s
all like &quot;have you got any bark?&quot;
No, I have not got any bark.

I didn&#39;t know I was
supposed to be gathering bark.
And what bark?
There&#39;s bark everywhere, it&#39;s a fucking forest.

Turns out you&#39;re supposed to look for
where the trees have broken out in tree zits and

burst one with a brief unskippable
minigame before being informed you&#39;re getting shitty

bark because you should have gathered
it during the night or while standing on one
leg.

I&#39;m not gonna plan my fucking schedule
around side hustling as a tree beautician game.

I&#39;m way behind on my have
some actual fucking fun quota.

Remember when games didn&#39;t need a
fucking x-ray specs mechanic to let you know what was
important because you could just tell?

Because it&#39;d be in a bright red rotating box
and wasn&#39;t concealed among sixteen non-interactive
vegetation assets?

Avatar Fapping in Pondwater has, like
many Ubisoft sandboxes lately, the option to turn

objective markers off so you have to
find things based on vague location clues.

To keep gameplay more explorative
and less about beelining to thing on map.

Like Disneyland closes in two hours
and there&#39;s four rides you haven&#39;t been on yet.

But I had to turn the objective markers
back on pretty quick, cause even when I was in

the right part of uselessly spectacular
scenery I could be ten feet from the objective and

walk straight past it cause it was
hidden by a cluster of hooluevian fireworks shrubs.
Yes, Tiz Beauty kills this beast.
It&#39;s a recurring issue.

There&#39;s an occasional detective mission
where you look for clues in a crime scene and pair

them together to draw conclusions, and
which ones you have to pair together always felt
really arbitrary.

Some broken arrows, and a dude who was
killed with some arrows, those aren&#39;t connected at
all.
Thic-o.

You&#39;re supposed to pair the broken
arrows with the tin of an open sponge pudding you

haven&#39;t noticed yet, cause it&#39;s tiny and
ten metres away and camouflaged against a golden
syrup bush.

It was during one of these scavenger
hunts that I finally lost patience and kicked Avatar

fucked up priorities in the head,
because the gameplay was a bore and the story failed

to make me give a single cerulean skidmark for
these interchangeable blue one-with-natria-than-thou
dullards and their bullshit problems.

Oh no, we&#39;re being victimised by the
little smelly fragile people who haven&#39;t had their

every need and want in life
fucking handed to them by their environment.

Suppose we&#39;d better kill them all and
get back to our difficult life of parties and
finger-painting.
Oh what a bore.

Why don&#39;t you stick a branch up your
arse and complain about it on tree Reddit.
